title: Printing Techniques in Art - Multiple Choice Questions
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Painting - Block Printing, Vegetable Printing, and Finger Printing

questions.question: What is a mural in art?
options: Any artwork painted or applied directly on a wall, ceiling or other large permanent surface
questions.explanation: A mural is any artwork painted or applied directly on a wall, ceiling or another large permanent surface.

questions.question: How long have human beings been painting according to rock painting evidence?
questions.explanation: As evident from the rock paintings, human beings have been painting for more than 30,000 years.

questions.question: Which ancient mural sites in India date from 100 CE to 600 CE?
options: Ajanta, Ellora, Bagh, Badami and Sittalavasal
questions.explanation: From the early rock paintings to the ancient murals in Ajanta, Ellora, Bagh, Badami and Sittalavasal (100 CE - 600 CE), mural art has developed significantly.

questions.question: What are the chief mediums of mural art?
options: Fresco, tempera, oil colour, watercolour, engraving and glass
questions.explanation: Mural art's chief mediums are fresco, tempera, oil colour, watercolour, engraving and glass.

questions.question: What materials are blocks for printing made with?
questions.explanation: Blocks for printing are made with wood, rubber, wax, soap etc. The desired figure is traced on the flat surface, and the superfluous parts are carved away.

questions.question: What is the advantage of block printing technique?
options: A large number of uniform copies can be created in a short time
Only one copy can be made
questions.explanation: The advantage of the block printing technique is that a large number of copies can be created in a short time, and all copies are uniform.

questions.question: How long can printing blocks be used?
options: Depending on what they are made with, blocks could be used for years
questions.explanation: Depending on what they are made with, blocks could be used for years, making them a durable tool for creating multiple prints.

questions.question: What products can be made using block printing?
options: Greeting cards, gifts, stationery, paper bags, lamp shades, and more
questions.explanation: Block printing could be used for making products like greeting cards, gifts, stationery, paper bags, and lamp shades. The list is endless.

questions.question: What is linocut in printing?
options: A printing technique where designs are carved on a linoleum block
questions.explanation: Linocut is a printing technique where the design for printing has been engraved/carved on a linoleum block.

questions.question: How is the design carved on a lino block?
questions.explanation: The design is carved on a lino block with a knife. Once the carving is finished, colour is spread on a flat surface for printing.

questions.question: What is the process after carving the lino block?
options: The carved surface is brought in contact with colour, then pressed onto drawing sheet
questions.explanation: After carving, colour is spread on a flat surface. The carved surface of the block is brought in contact with the colour and lifted. The block is then gently pressed onto the drawing sheet to create the imprint.

questions.question: What vegetables can be used for printing blocks?
options: Potato/yam/sweet potato, okra/ladyfinger, capsicum/bell pepper, onion, lotus stem
questions.explanation: Potato/yam/sweet potato, okra/ladyfinger, capsicum/bell pepper, onion, and lotus stem are cut cross-section-wise to obtain decorative shapes and used as blocks.

questions.question: What shapes do okra, capsicum and lotus stem yield when cut cross-section-wise?
questions.explanation: Okra/ladyfinger, capsicum/bell pepper, and lotus stem when cut cross-section-wise, yield pretty floral shapes.

questions.question: What can be printed using potato/yam/sweet potato blocks?
questions.explanation: A large potato/yam/sweet potato cut length- or cross-section-wise could be used for making a block for printing numerals, letters or simple shapes.

questions.question: Why should numerals and letters be carved as mirror images in vegetable blocks?
options: So the numerals or letters come out right in print
questions.explanation: Care needs to be taken to carve mirror images of the numerals and letters, so the numerals or letters come out right in print when transferred to paper.

questions.question: What was created in the vegetable block print example described?
options: Floral, leaf and animal shapes including tortoises
questions.explanation: The work was created combining different floral, leaf and animal shapes. The flowers and leaves look real, and so do the tortoises printed with capsicum/bell pepper block.

questions.question: What technique uses thumb and finger impressions for creating images?
questions.explanation: The thumb and finger printing technique uses thumb and finger impressions for creating images using ink, watercolour, oil colour, poster or acrylic colours.

questions.question: What colors can be used in thumb and finger printing?
options: Ink, watercolour, oil colour, poster or acrylic colours
questions.explanation: Thumb and finger printing can use ink, watercolour, oil colour, poster or acrylic colours, offering great variety and creativity.

questions.question: How is the colour applied in thumb printing technique?
options: The tip of the finger or thumb is smeared with colour and pressed onto surface
questions.explanation: The tip of the finger or the thumb is smeared with colour and pressed onto the surface to be painted, leaving a textured image.

questions.question: What is used to finish thumb print artwork?
options: A few pencil, pen or brush strokes to give new forms
questions.explanation: The textured image left by thumb/finger printing could be given a new form using a few pencil, pen or brush strokes to develop the impression into complete figures.

questions.question: What animals were created in the thumb printing example?
questions.explanation: In the example 'Bear, Tiger and Birds,' the bear and tiger were created using sole and palm impressions, and birds were created with thumbprints.

questions.question: How were birds created in the thumb printing example?
options: Thumbprints turned into birds with judicious brush strokes
questions.explanation: The birds roosting on a tree branch were created with thumbprints. Judicious brush strokes turned a few thumb prints into a lively flock of birds.

questions.question: What body parts were used to create the bear and tiger?
questions.explanation: The bear and tiger were created using sole and palm impressions, respectively. Brushwork was then used to develop the outline into full-fledged images.

questions.question: What adds dimension to thumb and finger print artwork?
questions.explanation: The print's texture adds dimension and makes the images life-like, which is a unique characteristic of thumb and finger printing.

questions.question: Where did printing originate according to the text?
options: In folk art, used by common people for decoration
questions.explanation: Printing is a centuries-old technique which has its roots in folk art. Common people used rudimentary printing to decorate walls, floors, terracotta ware and even their bodies.

questions.question: What did common people use for early printing?
options: Natural colours and their palms and fingertips
questions.explanation: Common people used natural colours and their palms and fingertips to create murals on walls and floors, which was the beginning of printing techniques.

questions.question: What materials were gradually used for making printing blocks?
options: Various vegetables, clay, stone and wood
questions.explanation: Gradually people began to use various vegetables, clay, stone and wood for making blocks to create elaborate designs.

questions.question: How did printing develop into textile printing?
options: Using blocks with raised printing surfaces, which were inked and pressed onto fabric
questions.explanation: Over the ages, printing developed into a textile-printing technique using blocks with raised printing surfaces, which were inked and then pressed onto the fabric to create fancy sheets and dress material.

questions.question: What was printing technique further developed for?
questions.explanation: The textile printing technique was further developed to print documents and books, expanding the application of printing technology.

questions.question: What is unique about vegetable block printing compared to other techniques?
options: The figures are similar but not exactly the same due to natural variations
questions.explanation: This technique is used when the same shape is repeated, but very slight changes in shape are acceptable. The figures thus printed are similar but not the same due to natural variations in vegetables.

questions.question: Why is block printing called a 'system' that doesn't require finishing separately?
options: The system of printing allows images to be finished in one go
questions.explanation: This system of printing does not require the images to be finished separately - they are complete when printed.

questions.question: What effect does using more than one colour create in linocut?
questions.explanation: The use of more than one colour in linocut creates an ambience of vibrancy and makes the print more dynamic.

questions.question: What creates a three-dimensional feel in linocut prints?
options: The combination and juxtaposition of curves and straight lines, floral and geometric shapes
questions.explanation: The print gives a feel of being three-dimensional through the harmonious blend and inner balance in the combination and juxtaposition of curves and straight lines, floral and geometric shapes.

questions.question: What ritual use did common people make of early printing?
options: To decorate walls, floors, terracotta ware and even their bodies for certain rituals
questions.explanation: Common people used rudimentary printing to decorate walls, floors, terracotta ware and even their bodies for certain rituals, showing its cultural and religious significance.

questions.question: What happens after capsicum impressions are made in vegetable printing?
options: Paint and brush are used to turn them into tortoises or join floral shapes
questions.explanation: Paint and brush have been used for turning capsicum/bell pepper impressions into tortoises and joining the floral and leaf shapes to create images of plants.

questions.question: What makes mural art permanent?
options: It is painted or applied directly on walls, ceilings or other large permanent surfaces
questions.explanation: Mural art now includes large panels stuck on a wall or ceiling permanently, making it a lasting form of art that becomes part of the architecture.

questions.question: What quality is remarkable in the thumb print 'Bear, Tiger and Birds' composition?
questions.explanation: The composition and colour combination in the 'Bear, Tiger and Birds' work is remarkable, showing artistic skill even in this simple technique.

questions.question: How do brush strokes enhance thumb printing?
options: They turn impressions into lively, full-fledged images
questions.explanation: Brushwork is used to develop the outline into full-fledged images. Judicious brush strokes turn impressions into lively figures, and details like tree branches and leaves make scenes come alive.

questions.question: What materials can be decorated using thumb and finger printing?
options: Different kinds of materials to make tasteful utility and decorative products
questions.explanation: This technique can be used for painting different kinds of materials to make tasteful utility and decorative products, showing its versatility.

questions.question: What is the origin purpose of art according to the text?
options: To communicate ideas when there was no spoken language
questions.explanation: Man first began to draw and paint images to communicate his ideas to other human beings when there was no spoken language. The history of art documents the aspirations and values of mankind.
